source.title: Comparative Test of the Energy Efficiency of Three Different Bulldozer Models
source.notes: Advantage Vol. 15 No. 3. Controlled test track (2.1 km per sequence, eight passes with half the laps pulling a 7.5 t sled) comparing Cat D7R mechanical, John Deere 950J hydrostatic, and Cat D7E diesel-electric drives.

speeds: low travel: deck building / heavy push

drives.label: Caterpillar D7R (mechanical planetary transmission)
notes: Acts as the baseline for 200+ hp support tractors still using mechanical drivetrains.
Low-speed work increases fuel burn by ~16% per hour relative to the high-speed grading sequence.

drives.label: John Deere 950J (dual-path hydrostatic)
notes: Consumes ~25% less fuel per hour than the mechanical Cat D7R during high-speed grading.
Hydrostatic control keeps low-speed fuel use below the high-speed sequence (no penalty when throttled back).

drives.label: Caterpillar D7E (diesel-electric)
notes: Electric drive delivers the lowest energy intensity (â‰ˆ28% lower L/hr than the mechanical baseline during high-speed work).
Low-speed operation further reduces fuel burn, so no penalty applies when travelling slowly or working wet soils.
